title: Mongolian Beef and Spring Onions Recipe
description: This Mongolian beef recipe features crispy slices of flank steak with a sweet soy-based sauce and green onions for a restaurant-quality dish at home!

with green onions has a soy-based sauce for a Chinese-style beef dish. Best served over soft rice noodles or rice. Original recipe (1X) yields 4 servings 2 teaspoons vegetable oil 1 tablespoon finely chopped garlic ½ teaspoon grated fresh ginger root ⅔ cup dark brown sugar ½ cup soy sauce ½ cup water 1 pound beef flank steak, sliced 1/4 inch thick on the diagonal ¼ cup cornstarch 1 cup vegetable oil for frying 2 bunches green onions, cut in 2-inch lengths Directions Gather all ingredients. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Heat 2 teaspoons of vegetable oil in a saucepan over medium heat. Add garlic and ginger; cook and stir until fragrant, about 30 seconds. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Stir in brown sugar, soy sauce, and water. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Increase heat to medium-high; stir until sauce boils and slightly thickens, about 4 minutes. Remove sauce from the heat and set aside. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Place beef into a large bowl; add cornstarch and mix until beef is thoroughly coated. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Set aside until most of the cornstarch has been absorbed, about 10 minutes. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Heat vegetable oil in a deep skillet to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Shake excess cornstarch from beef slices and drop into hot oil, a few at a time, stirring briefly and frying until edges become crisp, about 2 minutes. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Remove beef with a large slotted spoon; drain on paper towels. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Remove excess oil from the skillet, then heat the skillet over medium heat; add beef slices and stir in prepared sauce. Add green onions and bring to a boil; cook until the onions have just softened and are bright green, about 1 to 2 minutes. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Serve and enjoy! Add Your Photo Photos of Mongolian Beef and Spring Onions 01 of 402 Photo by  Dotdash Meredith Food Studios 02 of 402 Photo by  dave 01/28/2025 I added slivered almonds 03 of 402 Photo by  Amy Nissan 04/18/2024 Easy and delicious. There was probably a bit too much sauce, I didn’t use it all. My husband likes his spicy, so he adds a little heat on the side. Definitely will make this again! 04 of 402 Photo by  PMtz19 01/03/2024 I liked this recipe but I got side tracked and over cooked the steak as it was pretty dry, but that was my fault and not the receipe's. When I went to use the green onion, it was pretty wilted so I had to make a last minute decision to use a white onion and cook it with the meat.I definitely need to re-visit this recipe again and give it my full attention. 05 of 402 Photo by  postdesrapides 10/16/2023 Way too much sodium and sugar. I tweaked it for a cooking demo and all my samples for the crowd were gone! Diabetics would like mine better. I put it in a crock to have enough while I cooked another batch. 06 of 402 Photo by  nakita0151 02/09/2022 Love this recipe. One thing I would change is the soy sauce, I suggest going for a low sodium soy sauce instead.
